qcards.flippedFaceText: 3 out of 4 times in level 2 conditions.
Re-enter and roll in calm conditions, paddle boat back.
Effectively manage the rescue of a victim who has been separated from boat in current < 3 knots or in a rock garden with small breaking waves.

As the leader of a group manage a single tow (one person requiring assistance) for less than 30 minutes. Select an appropriate area to land a towed boat along an exposed coastline. Demonstrate effective quick release, re-deployment of personal tow system and the ability to quickly switch towers. Capsize, release and roll while towing in calm conditions.
Effectively manage the launching of a group and self in surf < 1 meter.
Select an appropriate place to land a group along an exposed coastline with surf. Manage the successful landing of a group and self in surf < 1 meter.

Maintain sufficient speed and directional control while paddling in a head, beam and stern wind of near 20 knots over a distance of 1 nautical mile without the use of skegs and rudders. Torso rotation must be evident.

Frequently link strokes and employ edging to manoeuvre around rocks, in current, surf and other obstacles. Demonstrate an effective eddy turn in current < 3 knots. Demonstrate an effective ferry-angle across current < 3 knots.
Remain upright and demonstrate safe positioning of body while broached and braced into a wave of height < 1 meter. No preparation or set up permitted; usage of braces must be real and necessary.

Use appropriate arm and/or hand signals to land a paddler in surf < 1 meter. Produce on demand, a group communication device appropriate to the area (VHF radio, sat phone, cell phone) and flares at any time while on the water.

Piloting: identify 3 out of 4 landmarks in a given area using transits, handrails, backstops and/or bearings. Dead Reckoning: From land, plot an accurate dead reckoning course identifying heading, distance and estimated time and paddle said course in low visibility conditions (night or fog). The target should less than 1 nautical mile in distance and distinctive.

In a logbook provide, in writing, 3-days of prior weather information and a personal forecast for departure date. Regularly use and interpret a personal log of weather observations and professional forecasts to assist a group plan a route while on an overnight trip. Identify two likely areas on a chart with land/wind interactions such as gap winds, clapotis, etc. for level 2 conditions.

Demonstrate the effective and efficient management of simple scenarios in level 2 conditions such as hypothermia, fear, seasickness, dislocated shoulder, or the inability of a paddler to paddle a beam wind. Candidate will direct the resolution of a scenario, demonstrating wise utilisation of group resources and appropriate members of the party to resolve problems. Demonstrates good 'expedition behaviour', frequently assisting with camp chores such as cooking, cleaning, setting up tarps, looking after camp, other participants and group equipment. Usually selects leadership styles appropriate to the group and situation. While journeying in Level 2 conditions, work to ensure the group is close enough to allow for visual and clear audio contact.

Use resources to identify potential hazards along an exposed coastline with frequent landing zones. Facilitate a group's understanding of those potential hazards and the group's acceptance or rejection of route's hazards. Use tide tables to calculate times of high and low water. Determine a ferry angle for crossing a current. File a written float-plan for the group

As part of a trip planning exercise, access and use at least three different resources, to identify hazards or points of interest about a proposed route through level 2 conditions. Such resources may include but are not limited to, the names of other paddlers, guidebooks, trip reports, names of local boaters, sailing directions and/or local weather guides.
Tidal station: Charlottetown (01700). +2:00 HW. Above 7 feet range. Slack water. Surf on ebb.
Tidal station: 8414112 Blue Hill Harbor. +2:10 LW. Above 12 feet range. Surf on flood.
Tidal station: Saint John (00065). +4:20 LW. Surf on flood. For corroboration use +2:50 LW Burncoat Head.
Tidal station: Yarmouth (00365). +2:30 HW. Above 11 feet range. Surf on ebb. 2:30 hours after high water the current starts to increase.

qcards.faceText: Brier Island (LW for Gull - play on flood, HW for Peter's Channel - play on ebb)
qcards.flippedFaceText: Tidal station: Westport (00340). For Gull Rock use LW. Above 16 feet range. Surf on flood. For Peter's Channel use -0:30 HW. Surf on ebb.
Tidal station: Tusket (00378). LW. Work the flood tide.
Tidal station: Little Harbour (00497). Best 1h after HW or 2h after LW.

qcards.faceText: What is the meaning of each letter in TTPPEE?
qcards.flippedFaceText: Technical, Tactical, Physical, Psychological, Equipment  and Environment.

qcards.faceText: What do we mean by Shared Mental Model?
qcards.flippedFaceText: Shared knowledge that enables team members to predict the needs of the task and anticipate the actions of other team members, allowing them to adjust their behavior accordingly.

qcards.faceText: What are the 6 categories of paddlers of a group (by Adam Harmer)?
qcards.flippedFaceText: 1.Pilots - copilots, 2.Participants - actively engaged, 3.Passengers - here to go to that island and back, 4.Prisoners - spouses, kids, dates, 5.Protesters - chronic complainers, 6.Pigs - consumers of everything.
The direction from a position toward a destination, expressed in degrees.
Direction of travel taking into consideration the tide (and the wind), expressed in degrees.
Heading is the direction your boat is pointing at, expressed in degrees.
Must show workings of a roll and have confidence to set up and attempt several times before wet exiting.
Complete a solo re-entry in level 2 conditions (no time limit) while maintaining contact with boat and paddle.
Perform an assisted rescue as both victim and rescuer in approximately 1 minute in level 2 conditions.
Have a tow system accessible and ready at all times appropriate while on the water. Participate, as a member of a team, in a challenging towing scenario for less than 30 minutes.
Launch as part of a group in surf < 1 meter.
Land as part of a group in surf < 1 meter.

Maintain sufficient speed and directional control while paddling in a head, beam and stern wind of less than 20 knots over a distance of 1 nautical mile without the use of skegs and rudders. Torso rotation should be evident.
Demonstrate consistent use of edging to assist turning. Demonstrate the effective linking of strokes to perform a bow rudder, low brace turn and high brace turn.
Remain upright and demonstrate safe positioning of body while broached and braced into a wave of height < 1 meter. Preparation and set up permitted.
Understand appropriate arm and/or hand signals to land in surf < 1 meter.

Piloting: identify 2 out of 4 landmarks in a given area using transits, handrails, backstops and/or bearings. Dead (deductive) Reckoning: From Sea, plot an accurate dead reckoning course identifying heading, distance and estimated time. Follow bearing and arrive at desired location. Participate in a paddle in low visibility conditions (night or fog).

In a logbook provide, in writing, 3-days of prior weather information and a personal forecast for departure date. Use a professional forecast to assist a group plan a day's journey while on an overnight trip. Identify a likely area on a chart with land/wind interactions such as gap winds, clapotis, etc. for level 2 conditions.

Demonstrates good 'expedition behaviour', frequently assisting with camp chores such as cooking, cleaning, setting up tarps, looking after camp, other participants and group equipment. While journeying in Level 2 conditions, maintain group and personal separation that allows for visual and clear audio contact within the group and/or with the designated paddle buddy.
Actively participate, as a member of a group, in planning and packing for an overnight trip. Take appropriate personal equipment and clothing appropriate for an overnight trip.
Identify at least 3 resources to assist in the planning of an overnight trip to an unfamiliar area.
